DataElement.preferredName: Breast Precancerous Condition Histopathologic Examination Outcome
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The result of a precancerous breast tissue examination using light or electron microscopy and employing cytochemical and immunocytochemical stain.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest._A pathological process with signs indicating it may become cancerous.  Representative examples include leukoplakia, dysplastic nevus, actinic keratosis, xeroderma pigmentosum, and intraepithelial neoplasia._The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Concepts.definition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathological processes that tend eventually to become malignant. (From Dorland, 27th ed):The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

Concepts.definition: A pathological process with signs indicating it may become cancerous.  Representative examples include leukoplakia, dysplastic nevus, actinic keratosis, xeroderma pigmentosum, and intraepithelial neoplasia.
The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Top level term which includes Biological Markers, Risk Factors, and Prognostic Factors.

DataElementConcept.origin: MCL:Molecular and Cellular Characterization of Screened Lesions
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 3/18/22 mr Released per SME and DCT.   2/20/19 jk created for MCL PCA Breast.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest._The microscopic study of characteristic tissue abnormalities by employing various cytochemical and immunocytochemical stains._The result of an action.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Mixed Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Mixed Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Involving or composed of different kinds.: A carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.  It is also known as DCIS.  There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane.  Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis.  The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

Concepts.definition: Involving or composed of different kinds.

A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Benign papillary proliferation within the ductal system of the breast parenchyma.

Concepts.definition: Benign papillary proliferation within the ductal system of the breast parenchyma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An intraductal papillary carcinoma in which the neoplastic epithelial cells are arranged in micropapillary patterns.

Concepts.longName: Breast Micropapillary Ductal Carcinoma In Situ
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of neoplastic epithelial cells arranged in micropapillary patterns.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast characterized by the presence of a cribriform architectural pattern.

Concepts.longName: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Cribriform Pattern
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of a cribriform architectural pattern.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Mosaic Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ, Solid Type

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Mosaic Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ, Solid Type
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An individual containing two or more populations of genetically different cells that arose from a single zygote.: A ductal carcinoma in situ of the breast in which the tumor cells fill the ductal spaces as solid sheets.

Concepts.definition: An individual containing two or more populations of genetically different cells that arose from a single zygote.

Concepts.longName: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Solid Type
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ in which the tumor cells fill the ductal spaces as solid sheets.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Ductal carcinoma in situ involving nipple skin (Paget disease)

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Ductal carcinoma in situ involving nipple skin (Paget disease)
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm in which there is infiltration of the skin overlying the breast by neoplastic large cells with abundant pale cytoplasm and large nuclei with prominent nucleoli (Paget cells). It is almost always associated with an intraductal or invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. The clinical features include focal skin reddening, and eczema. Retraction of the nipple may sometimes occur.

Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm in which there is infiltration of the skin overlying the breast by neoplastic large cells with abundant pale cytoplasm and large nuclei with prominent nucleoli (Paget cells). It is almost always associated with an intraductal or invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. The clinical features include focal skin reddening, and eczema. Retraction of the nipple may sometimes occur.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Low Grade Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Low Grade Ductal Breast Carcinoma In Situ
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Ductal breast carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of small, monomorphic neoplastic cells that form cribriform, micropapillary, or solid patterns. The nuclei are uniform and mitotic figures are rare.

Concepts.longName: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Low Grade
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of small, monomorphic neoplastic cells that form cribriform, micropapillary, or solid patterns. The nuclei are uniform and mitotic figures are rare.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A benign (not cancer) condition in which there are more cells than normal in the breast lobules and the cells look abnormal under a microscope. Having atypical lobular hyperplasia increases the risk of breast cancer.

Concepts.definition: A neoplastic process that arises from the terminal ductal lobular unit of the breast parenchyma.  It is usually solitary and confined to a single lobular unit.  It is characterized by the presence of a monomorphic epithelial proliferation in a cribriform, micropapillary, or solid growth pattern.  Focal architectural features of low grade ductal carcinoma in situ are present.  There is an increased risk for development of invasive breast carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neoplastic ductal proliferative lesion of the breast characterized by the formation of secondary lumens and prominent intraductal proliferation of a heterogeneous cellular population that may include epithelial cells, myoepithelial cells, or metaplastic apocrine cells.

Concepts.definition: A neoplastic ductal proliferative lesion of the breast characterized by the formation of secondary lumens and prominent intraductal proliferation of a heterogeneous cellular population that may include epithelial cells, myoepithelial cells, or metaplastic apocrine cells.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Comedo Type

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Comedo Type
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of sheets of tumor cells with evidence of central necrosis and associated karyorrhectic/nuclear debris.

Concepts.longName: Breast Ductal Carcinoma In Situ, Comedo Type
Concepts.definition: Breast ductal carcinoma in situ characterized by the presence of sheets of tumor cells with evidence of central necrosis and associated karyorrhectic/nuclear debris.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Information regarding the subject is unknown or inaccessible at this time.

Concepts.definition: Information regarding the subject is unknown or inaccessible at this time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.  It is also known as DCIS.  There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane.  Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis.  The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

ReferenceDocuments.description: Report all that apply, to describe precancers with multiple cell types included - separate by a pipe (|) Example:  DCIS-Comedo|DCIS-Papillary|DCIS-Cribiform
